author: Lucy Marks
title: Do not ban police from using tasers on children: NT Chief Minister
text:
Map: Palmerston 0830 
Police should not be banned from using tasers on children, the Northern Territory's Chief Minister says. 
The National Children's Commissioner Megan Mitchell this week called for the weapons not to be used on children after viewing footage obtained by the ABC which shows a 12-year-old boy being tasered in the back as he runs away from police at a petrol station. 
Mr Gunner said in a statement an offender's age was not always immediately obvious and police should not be held back from carrying out their duty. 
"No one wants to see children tasered, but police need to be allowed to do their jobs to protect Territorians," he said. 
"Police need to be allowed to make the best decisions they can during live situations." 
The 12-year-old boy had been part of a trio who went on a joyride through Palmerston in November last year, and police said at the time it was fortunate no children were injured or killed. Tasering of child 'unlawful and improper': Court Photo: Three boys were confronted by police at a Bakewell petrol station. (Supplied: Facebook) 
The boy was a passenger in the stolen car when it pulled into a Bakewell petrol station where police confronted them. 
The court heard the unarmed 12-year-old was tasered by Sergeant Benjamin Watson from a distance of three metres when he tried to run away. 
The child pleaded guilty to unlawful use of a vehicle, but not guilty to resisting arrest, escaping custody and driving a motor vehicle while unlicensed. 
The court heard tasers were not allowed to be used against a young child, as well as near volatile liquids or near a car that might lose control, unless there were exceptional circumstances. 
Judge Fong Lim said there were no extraordinary circumstances that warranted the use of the taser on the boy, especially so close to a petrol bowser. 
"At the time Watson raised his taser he was aware of these things," Judge Fong Lim said. 
She said there was "no immediate danger to Watson" and "the taser should not have been deployed". 
Judge Fong Lim ruled the offending of the boy "was not of a particularly serious nature" and the "impropriety of raising the taser [by officer Watson] is great". 
The boy, whom the court heard had never been in trouble with police before, received a six-month good behaviour bond. 
The officer told the Children's Court he was worried the boy would get in another car and be a danger to the public and officers at the scene. 
Ms Mitchell said governments should review their guidelines for the use of tasers to support police in apprehending child offenders without the use of tasers. 
The ABC contacted the NT Police Association but it declined to comment.
